descendants.content:
@RARohde

#Business as usual is leading to #disaster.

There are still hundreds of billions of dollars of planned investments for fossil fuels. Not because renewables are not technically or financially viable, but because estimates are the fossil fuel investments will have higher returns on investment.

That is only because #fossilfuel investments are able to externalise so much of their costs. Aside from ongoing subsidies, there is a failure to properly account and attribute damages [foreseeable damages] to the liable businesses and industries.

Insurance companies must take action to recover the health, property and business losses caused by greenhouse gas emissions.

The Economist has reported homeowners face a $25trn bill from climate change. Property, the world’s biggest asset class, is also its most vulnerable. Health costs and associated health insurance impacts may well challenge that.

Also add in financial losses to industries like tourism, construction and agriculture, along with transport infrastructure.
https://global.insure-our-future.com/about/#demands

Demand 5 - Explore ways to bring fossil fuel companies to court in order to make polluters rather than insurance customers pay for the growing costs of climate disasters.
https://www.activesustainability.com/climate-change/100-companies-responsible-71-ghg-emissions/

100 COMPANIES ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR 71% OF GHG EMISSIONS
https://www.statista.com/statistics/1058434/leading-ghg-emissions-fossil-fuel-companies-globally/

account.note:
I don't want to change the world.
Just the atmosphere and the oceans.

card.title: About - Insure Our Future Global
card.description: Insure Our Future is a group of NGOs and social movements that hold the insurance industry accountable for its role in the climate crisis.

descendants.content:
@RARohde

#Fossilfuels are no longer essential or critical, they are a choice. And obviously a poor one for both environmental as well as financial reasons.

#Investment in clean energy likely to be double figure for fossil fuels in 2024, according to the International Energy Agency.

“The global energy watchdog has predicted that investment in clean energy including #renewables and nuclear power as well as #electricvehicles, power grids, #energystorage, low-emissions fuels, efficiency improvements and #heatpumps will reach $2tn this year.

The global clean energy investment figure, which topped fossil fuels for the first time last year, is likely to be double the $1tn forecast for coal, gas and oil in 2024, the IEA said.

“For every dollar going to fossil fuels today, almost $2 are invested in clean energy,” said the IEA’s executive director, Fatih Birol.”

Fossil fuel consumers and producers need to be compensating insurance companies for the rising frequency and damages to health, property, and business losses.

#Governments should be removing any legislative protections that fossil fuels have as “critical infrastructure”, as it no longer is. It is now just a choice, with more affordable alternative available.

If investment is now more than 2 to 1 against fossil fuels, then it would seem its future status is as an “alternative fuel”. #Electricity, #solar, #wind, #batterystorage, [green] hydrogen, these are all the new mainstream, “critical infrastructure”.

https://www.theguardian.com/business/article/2024/jun/06/investment-in-clean-energy-likely-to-be-double-figure-for-fossil-fuels-in-2024-iea-says

https://www.carbonbrief.org/daily-brief/godfathers-of-climate-chaos-un-chief-calls-for-global-fossil-fuel-advertising-ban/

https://solarstoragextra.com/clean-energy-investments-to-eclipse-fossil-fuels-iea-says/

https://www.proactiveinvestors.co.uk/companies/news/1049277/clean-energy-spending-to-be-double-that-of-fossil-fuel-report-1049277.html

card.title: Investment in clean energy likely to be double figure for fossil fuels in 2024, IEA says
card.description: Low-carbon electricity investment driven by solar projects but oil and gas spending still too high to meet climate goals

descendants.content:
@RARohde

“Senator J.D. Vance, Republican of Ohio, is a strong supporter of the oil and gas industry, opposes solar power and electric vehicles, and has said climate change is not a threat.”

#Capitalism is in the process of killing the #fossilfuel industry.

Like it did the steam train, the telegraph and horse and buggy.

#Renewables and energy storage are now cheaper than fossil fuels. And on a continuing declining cost curve [getting cheaper in future].

2024 has $2Tn renewable to $1Tn fossil fuel #investments. That ratio will see declining fossil fuel investments, and returns.

The #Insurance Industry is already doing all of the calculations, they know the risk equations and factored in the additional financial costs to premiums. Also increasing and broadening the properties, industries and health impacts they will not insure anymore, or in future.

Ask your insurance companies when will they be suing to recover these additional financial costs?

If your insurance company is removing or dropping your cover, demand they maintain your coverage and seek financial compensation from the companies and industries that have been causing it. That should include compensation claims against the financiers and insurers of the companies and industries that are investing and planning ongoing and future emissions.

If your insurance company won’t do that, lobby your elected representatives.

Begin community outreach to build participation in class action against the insurance firms.

#climatecrisis #GlobalWarming #climate

descendants.content: @RARohde #AltText: a line graph of mean global temperature from Jan-Dec on the x axis and from 11°C to about 17.5°C on the y axis. There are many lines, ranging from the year 1850 to 2024. The lines are a bell curve peaking around July. Over time, the line shifts up and the most recent peaks are at least 1°C hotter than the oldest. In red, the line for 2023 overtakes the others in May and stays well above 2022. 2024, in black, has been hotter than 2023 for the entire year so far.

account.note:
She/her ♠️

 I want to be the very best cat lady, like no one ever was. Postdoctoral fellow at the Canadian Museum of Nature and University of Ottawa studying what intrinsic traits made large Arctic carnivores go extinct at the end of the Pleistocene.

I am interested in how life history affected extinction risk in the past and what that can tell us about extinction risks and conservation today.

 Ask me your questions about cats!

descendants.content:
@RARohde During the most recent glacial maximum (stadial, 23,000 to 11,000 years ago), the average global temperature was about 8°C, with polar regions experiencing average temperatures of -2°C. Ice-free periods over the past 500 million years correspond with average global temperatures of over 20°C.

Would that be better?

@premysljordak @RARohde

For our complex, stable tech-civilisation you need a stable environment.
If you don't want the comfort of a stable tech civilisation, what is the object for which one of your two alternatives is supposed to be "better"?
